rv.title: Radial Velocity Detection
rv.intro: The radial velocity method revolutionized astrobiology by enabling us to detect planets orbiting distant stars including potentially habitable worlds we could never see directly. This visualization uses real measurements from this planet's host star to simulate the subtle stellar wobble that revealed its existence. Watch as the synchronized views show how astronomers decode tiny Doppler shifts in starlight to discover new worlds across the galaxy.
rv.comparisonDescription: The RV amplitude (semi-amplitude K) indicates how much the star wobbles due to each planet. Larger amplitudes mean the planet has a stronger gravitational pull on its star, either because it's more massive, orbits closer, or both. Planets with amplitudes below ~1 m/s are extremely difficult to detect with current technology. This chart compares all planets in this system to show which ones create the most detectable stellar wobble.

noData.title: No Radial Velocity Data Available
noData.message: This planet was discovered using {{method}}, which doesn't provide RV measurements.
noData.example: For comparison, in our Solar System:
noData.jupiterExample: Jupiter causes the Sun to wobble at ~12 m/s
noData.earthExample: Earth causes ~0.09 m/s (undetectable with current technology)
noData.detectionLimit: Detection limit for modern spectrographs: ~1 m/s

explanation.dopplerContent: Just like an ambulance siren sounds higher-pitched as it approaches and lower as it moves away, light from a star shifts to bluer wavelengths when moving toward us and redder when moving away. Astronomers measure these tiny wavelength shifts in the star's spectral lines to detect its motion.
explanation.dopplerImageCaption: Radial velocity detection: As a planet orbits, it causes its host star to wobble. This motion produces a Doppler shift in the star's spectrum that we can measure from Earth.
explanation.wobbleContent: Planets and their host stars orbit around a common center of mass (barycenter). As a planet orbits, it tugs on the star, causing the star to 'wobble' back and forth. Larger planets or those closer to their stars cause more noticeable wobbles. For example, Jupiter causes our Sun to wobble at about 12 m/s, while Earth's effect is only 0.09 m/s; too small to detect with current technology.
explanation.discoveryContent: 51 Pegasi b was the first exoplanet discovered around a Sun-like star using the radial velocity method. Its RV amplitude of ~50 m/s and 4.2-day orbital period shocked astronomers, revealing a Jupiter-mass planet orbiting closer to its star than Mercury is to our Sun. This discovery introduced the 'Hot Jupiter' class of exoplanets and revolutionized our understanding of planetary systems.

transit.title: Transit Detection
transit.intro: The transit method is the most successful planet detection technique, responsible for discovering thousands of exoplanets including Earth-sized worlds. When a planet passes in front of its star from our viewpoint, it blocks a tiny fraction of the star's light. By measuring these periodic dips in brightness, astronomers can determine the planet's size, orbital period, and atmospheric composition.
transit.comparisonDescription: Transit depth directly reveals the planet's radius relative to its star. Deeper transits mean larger planets. This chart compares all transiting planets in this system.

noData.title: No Transit Data Available
noData.message: This planet was discovered using {{method}}, which doesn't provide transit measurements.
noData.example: For comparison, from a distant viewpoint:

explanation.geometryContent: Transit detection requires precise orbital alignment. The planet's orbit must be nearly edge-on from Earth's perspective. Only about 0.5-1% of randomly oriented planetary systems will transit as seen from Earth.
explanation.depthTitle: What Does Transit Depth Tell Us?
explanation.depthContent: The transit depth directly reveals the planet's size. It's proportional to (planet radius / star radius)¬≤. A Jupiter-sized planet blocks ~1% of light, while Earth blocks only ~0.008%.
explanation.timingContent: By measuring transits repeatedly, astronomers can detect gravitational tugs from other planets. These tiny timing variations reveal additional planets that might not transit themselves.

visualization.title: How We Visualize This Planet
visualization.intro: Our planet visualizations are generated procedurally using real scientific data from NASA's Exoplanet Archive. Here's how different properties influence what you see:

density.title: Density
density.description: Determines surface texture and composition. High-density worlds appear more rugged with retained impact craters (strong gravity holds surface features). Low-density "puffy" planets have smoother, more volatile-rich appearances.

insolation.title: Insolation Flux
insolation.description: The energy received from the host star. High insolation creates volcanic surfaces, lava glow, and active atmospheres. Low insolation produces ice coverage and frozen landscapes.

starTemp.title: Star Temperature
starTemp.description: Affects the lighting color. Planets around red dwarf stars have a warm orange tint, while those orbiting hot blue stars appear cooler and bluer.

planetType.title: Planet Type
planetType.description: Determines the base shader: Gas Giants show banded atmospheres with storms, Ice Giants have smooth blue-green methane atmospheres, and Rocky planets display terrain, craters, and possible atmospheres.

visualization.disclaimer: Note: These visualizations are artistic interpretations based on scientific data, not actual photographs. Each planet's unique seed ensures consistent appearance across sessions.

famous.title: Famous Worlds
famous.intro: Meet the celebrities of the exoplanet world. These are the planets that captured headlines, sparked our imagination, and changed how we think about our place in the cosmos.

nearest.title: Nearest Neighbors
nearest.intro: These worlds are practically next door in cosmic terms. Some lie within reach of potential future missions, making them prime candidates for detailed study.

habitable.title: Most Habitable
habitable.intro: If humanity ever finds a second home among the stars, it might be one of these worlds. Our habitability algorithm ranks these planets as the most promising candidates for life as we know it.

extreme.title: Extreme Worlds
extreme.intro: These planets push the boundaries of what we thought possible. From scorching hot worlds to gravitational oddballs, they challenge our understanding of planetary formation.

records.title: Record Breakers
records.intro: The champions of the exoplanet Olympics. These worlds hold the records for being the hottest, coldest, fastest, largest, and most ancient among all known exoplanets.

famous.proximaCenB: Our closest exoplanet neighbor at just 4.2 light-years away. Orbiting Proxima Centauri, the nearest star to our Sun, this rocky world sits in the habitable zone where liquid water could exist.
famous.trappist1e: The most Earth-like world in a remarkable system of seven planets. TRAPPIST-1 e receives similar energy from its star as Earth does from the Sun, making it a prime target in the search for life.
famous.kepler452b: Nicknamed 'Earth's Cousin', this was the first near-Earth-size planet found in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. Its 385-day orbit is remarkably similar to our own year.
famous.fiftyOnePegB: The planet that changed everything. Discovered in 1995, this was the first exoplanet found orbiting a Sun-like star, earning its discoverers the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics.
famous.kepler16b: A real-life Tatooine! This circumbinary planet orbits two stars, experiencing double sunsets. It proved that planets can form and survive in binary star systems.
famous.kepler186f: The first Earth-sized planet discovered in the habitable zone of another star. This milestone world showed that rocky planets the size of Earth exist in regions where life could thrive.

nearby.habitableZone: At {{distance}} light-years, this {{type}} orbits in its star's habitable zone. Its proximity makes it an excellent target for future observations and potential atmospheric studies.
nearby.multiPlanet: Just {{distance}} light-years away in a system of {{count}} known planets. Being so close to Earth, this system offers unique opportunities for detailed study.
nearby.default: One of our nearest cosmic neighbors at {{distance}} light-years. Close enough that future telescopes may be able to directly image this {{type}} and analyze its atmosphere.

habitable.score: With a habitability score of {{score}}/100, this world has the right combination of size, temperature, and stellar environment that could support liquid water on its surface.

extreme.ultraHot: A scorching inferno at {{temp}}K, hot enough to vaporize iron and titanium. On this ultra-hot world, metals rain from the sky and the day side glows like an ember.
extreme.puffy: An inflated giant with density of just {{density}} g/cm¬≥‚Äîless dense than styrofoam. Despite being larger than Jupiter, you could theoretically float on this cotton-candy world.
extreme.circumbinary: A world with two suns in its sky. This circumbinary planet orbits a pair of stars, creating spectacular double sunrises and sunsets like the fictional Tatooine.
extreme.ultraDense: An iron world with incredible density of {{density}} g/cm¬≥, denser than any planet in our solar system. This compact world likely has a massive metallic core.
extreme.eccentric: A wild orbit with eccentricity of {{ecc}}. This planet swings from scorching close approaches to frigid distant passes, experiencing extreme seasonal temperature swings.

records.hottest: The hottest known exoplanet at {{temp}}K‚Äîhotter than most stars! Its atmosphere is hot enough to break apart molecules into their component atoms.
records.coldest: The coldest known exoplanet at just {{temp}}K ({{tempC}}¬∞C). A frozen world where even gases like methane and nitrogen would freeze solid.
records.fastest: A year lasts just {{period}} on this speed demon! It orbits so close to its star that surface temperatures would vaporize rock.
records.largest: The largest known exoplanet at {{radius}} times Jupiter's radius. This bloated giant is so inflated by stellar radiation that it pushes the limits of planetary physics.
records.smallest: The tiniest confirmed exoplanet at {{radius}} Earth radii‚Äîsmaller than our Moon. Finding worlds this small shows how far our detection methods have come.
records.oldest: At {{age}} billion years old, this ancient system formed when the universe was young. If life ever arose here, it had billions of years more than Earth to evolve.

1992.title: First Exoplanets
1992.desc: Wolszczan & Frail discover the first confirmed exoplanets orbiting a pulsar, proving planets exist beyond our solar system.

1995.title: 51 Pegasi b
1995.desc: Mayor & Queloz detect the first exoplanet around a Sun-like star, earning them the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics.

2009.title: Kepler Launches
2009.desc: NASA's Kepler space telescope begins its mission, eventually discovering over 2,700 confirmed exoplanets.

2016.title: Proxima Centauri b
2016.desc: Discovery of an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone of our nearest stellar neighbor, just 4.2 light-years away.

2018.title: TESS Mission
2018.desc: The Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite begins an all-sky survey, finding planets around the brightest nearby stars.

today.title: 5,700+ Worlds
today.desc: We've now confirmed thousands of exoplanets, with many more candidates awaiting verification. The search continues.

project.title: Project Evolution
project.author_message: Greetings, Travelers! Guinetik here üë©‚ÄçüöÄ, your guide to the stars and beyond. I'm a software engineer and space enthusiast, and this project is a labor of love. It started as a way to learn Firebase, I thought, why not use NASA's exoplanet dataset to build a TripAdvisor for the stars, where future space travelers could leave reviews about the planets they visit? We began with TESS data and a simple catalog. Then I wanted to learn Three.js, so I gave this old project a complete makeover, adding 3D procedural planets, custom shaders, habitability scoring, and much more. Welcome aboard!

radius.title: Planet Radius
radius.description: The radius of a planet tells us how large it is compared to Earth. Planetary radii range from smaller than Mercury (0.4 Earth radii) to larger than Jupiter (11 Earth radii). A planet's radius, combined with its mass, helps us determine its composition‚Äîwhether it's a rocky world like Earth or a gas giant like Jupiter.
radius.example: Jupiter has a radius of 11.2 Earth radii, making it the largest planet in our solar system. Hot Jupiters can be even larger due to atmospheric inflation from intense stellar heat.
radius.technicalNote: Measured in Earth radii (R‚äï). Transit observations provide the most accurate radius measurements.
radius.funFact: Some 'puffy' exoplanets have lower density than styrofoam due to extreme heating from their nearby stars!

mass.title: Planet Mass
mass.description: A planet's mass determines its gravitational pull and, along with radius, reveals its composition. Massive planets tend to retain thick atmospheres and can significantly affect their host star's motion. Mass measurements help distinguish between rocky planets, ice giants, and gas giants.
mass.example: Earth has a mass of 1.0 M‚äï by definition. Jupiter is 318 times more massive, while some 'super-Earths' range from 2-10 Earth masses.
mass.technicalNote: Measured in Earth masses (M‚äï). Radial velocity measurements provide mass estimates.

density.title: Planet Density
density.description: Density reveals what a planet is made of. Rocky planets like Earth have densities around 5 g/cm¬≥, while gas giants like Jupiter are much less dense at 1.3 g/cm¬≥. Ultra-dense planets may have iron-rich cores, while 'puffy' planets can have densities lower than water.
density.example: Earth: 5.51 g/cm¬≥ (rocky), Jupiter: 1.33 g/cm¬≥ (gas), Saturn: 0.69 g/cm¬≥ (less dense than water!)
density.technicalNote: Calculated from mass and radius: œÅ = M / (4/3 √ó œÄ √ó R¬≥)

eqTemperature.title: Equilibrium Temperature
eqTemperature.description: This is the temperature a planet would have if it were in thermal equilibrium with its star's radiation, assuming it has no atmosphere. It's calculated from the star's brightness and the planet's distance. Planets hotter than 1,000 K are typically tidally locked to their stars.
eqTemperature.example: Earth: ~255 K (without atmosphere), Venus: ~730 K, Mercury: ~435 K. Hot Jupiters often exceed 1,500 K.
eqTemperature.technicalNote: Measured in Kelvin (K). Calculated from stellar temperature, radius, and orbital distance.

orbitalPeriod.title: Orbital Period
orbitalPeriod.description: The orbital period is how long a planet takes to complete one orbit around its star‚Äîessentially, the length of its year. Earth's period is 365.25 days. Some exoplanets orbit in mere hours, while others take thousands of years.
orbitalPeriod.example: Mercury: 88 days, Earth: 365 days, Hot Jupiter: 1-10 days, Distant planet: 1,000+ days
orbitalPeriod.technicalNote: Measured in Earth days. Derived from repeated transit or radial velocity observations.
orbitalPeriod.funFact: Some 'ultra-short period' planets orbit their stars faster than Earth rotates!

insolationFlux.title: Insolation Flux
insolationFlux.description: Insolation flux is the amount of stellar energy received by a planet per unit area. It's compared to Earth's insolation (1 S‚äï). Planets with very high insolation are extremely hot, while those with low insolation are frigid. This determines the planet's equilibrium temperature and climate.
insolationFlux.example: Earth: 1.0 S‚äï, Venus: 2.6 S‚äï (much hotter), Mercury: 6.9 S‚äï (extremely hot), Mars: 0.43 S‚äï (much colder)
insolationFlux.technicalNote: Measured in Earth insolation units (S‚äï). Calculated from stellar luminosity and orbital distance.
insolationFlux.funFact: Hot Jupiters can receive 1,000+ times Earth's insolation, making them far hotter than Venus!

planetType.title: Planet Type
planetType.description: Planet type is a classification based on size and composition. Sub-Earth planets are smaller than Earth (rocky), Super-Earths are 1-10 Earth masses (rocky), Neptune-like are smaller gas giants, and Gas Giants are massive hydrogen/helium worlds. Type helps predict what the planet might be like.
planetType.example: Earth: Earth-sized, Super-Earth: 2-5 Earth masses, Hot Jupiter: Gas giant in short orbit, Neptune-like: Ice giant
planetType.technicalNote: Classification based on radius and mass. Sub-Earth < 1.25 R‚äï, Super-Earth 1.25-2 R‚äï, Neptune-like 2-6 R‚äï, Gas Giant > 6 R‚äï

hostStar.title: Host Star
hostStar.description: The host star is the star that the planet orbits. The properties of the host star‚Äîits size, temperature, and age‚Äîdramatically affect the planet's climate and potential habitability. The star's name often becomes part of the planet's name.
hostStar.example: Our Sun hosts Earth, TRAPPIST-1 hosts 7 Earth-sized planets, Proxima Centauri hosts Proxima Centauri b
hostStar.technicalNote: From the Exoplanet Archive hostname field.

starTemperature.title: Star Temperature
starTemperature.description: A star's surface temperature determines its color and the type of light it emits. Cooler red dwarfs burn at 2,500-3,500 K, while our Sun is 5,778 K, and hot blue stars exceed 30,000 K. Stellar temperature directly affects the habitable zone‚Äîthe region where planets could have liquid water.
starTemperature.example: Red dwarf (M-type): 3,000 K (red glow), Sun (G-type): 5,778 K (yellow), Hot blue star (O-type): 40,000 K
starTemperature.technicalNote: Measured in Kelvin (K). Determined from spectral analysis.
starTemperature.funFact: Red dwarfs are the most common stars in the galaxy and can burn for trillions of years!

starRadius.title: Star Radius
starRadius.description: The radius of a star determines how large it appears in the sky and affects the size of its habitable zone. Our Sun has a radius of about 700,000 km. Red dwarfs are much smaller (0.1 R‚òâ), while red giants can be 1,000 times larger.
starRadius.example: Sun: 1.0 R‚òâ, Red dwarf: 0.1 R‚òâ, Red giant Betelgeuse: ~900 R‚òâ
starRadius.technicalNote: Measured in solar radii (R‚òâ). Determined from stellar models and eclipsing binary measurements.

starMass.title: Star Mass
starMass.description: A star's mass determines how long it will live and how bright it will be. More massive stars burn hotter and brighter but die younger. The Sun has a mass of 1 M‚òâ. The most massive stars are about 150 M‚òâ, while the smallest are about 0.08 M‚òâ.
starMass.example: Sun: 1.0 M‚òâ, Red dwarf: 0.08-0.5 M‚òâ, Blue giant: 5-10 M‚òâ
starMass.technicalNote: Measured in solar masses (M‚òâ). Determined from orbital mechanics and stellar models.

starLuminosity.title: Star Luminosity
starLuminosity.description: Luminosity is the total amount of energy a star emits per second. It's the primary factor in determining the size and location of a star's habitable zone. Our Sun has a luminosity of 1 L‚òâ. Luminosity increases dramatically with temperature and size.
starLuminosity.example: Sun: 1.0 L‚òâ, Sirius: 26 L‚òâ (much brighter), Red dwarf: 0.001-0.1 L‚òâ (much dimmer)
starLuminosity.technicalNote: Measured in solar luminosities (L‚òâ). Calculated from stellar models or observational data.

starSurfaceGravity.title: Surface Gravity
starSurfaceGravity.description: Surface gravity determines how strong the pull is on the star's surface. It depends on both the star's mass and radius. A more massive, compact star has higher surface gravity. Surface gravity affects how hydrogen and helium behave in a star's atmosphere.
starSurfaceGravity.example: Sun: log g = 4.83, White dwarf: log g > 8 (extreme compression), Red giant: log g = 1-2 (weak gravity)
starSurfaceGravity.technicalNote: Measured as log g (logarithm of surface gravity in cm/s¬≤). Values range from 0-10.

starMetallicity.title: Star Metallicity
starMetallicity.description: In astronomy, 'metallicity' means the abundance of elements heavier than helium (called 'metals'). Stars with higher metallicity tend to have more planets and are less likely to be on the main sequence. Our Sun has a metallicity of 0 dex by definition.
starMetallicity.example: Sun: 0.0 dex, Metal-rich star: +0.5 dex (twice as much heavy elements), Metal-poor star: -1.0 dex (10x less)
starMetallicity.technicalNote: Measured in dex (decimal magnitudes). Calculated by comparing spectral lines to solar values.
starMetallicity.funFact: Stars with higher metallicity are more likely to have planets, especially gas giants!

starAge.title: Star Age
starAge.description: The age of a star indicates how much of its life it has already lived. Young stars (< 1 billion years) can have unstable planetary systems, while old stars (> 10 billion years) have stable, mature systems. Age is estimated from stellar models and chemical composition.
starAge.example: Sun: 4.6 billion years old, Young star: < 100 million years, Old star: > 10 billion years
starAge.technicalNote: Measured in Gyr (billions of years). Age estimates have significant uncertainties.

starRotationPeriod.title: Rotation Period
starRotationPeriod.description: This is how long it takes for a star to complete one rotation on its axis. Younger stars rotate faster while older stars slow down due to magnetic braking. Rotation period affects stellar activity and can influence planets through stellar radiation.
starRotationPeriod.example: Sun: ~25 days (equator) to 35 days (poles), Young star: < 5 days, Old star: > 50 days
starRotationPeriod.technicalNote: Measured in days. Determined from photometric variations or spectroscopic measurements.

starSpectralType.title: Spectral Type
starSpectralType.description: Spectral type is determined by a star's temperature and color. The main types are O, B, A, F, G, K, M (from hottest to coolest), with subdivisions 0-9. Our Sun is a G2V star. Spectral type quickly tells astronomers a star's temperature and composition.
starSpectralType.example: O5: 50,000 K (blue), A0: 10,000 K (blue-white), G2: 5,778 K (yellow), M5: 3,200 K (red)
starSpectralType.technicalNote: From spectroscopic analysis. Format: Letter (temperature class) + Number (subclass 0-9) + Roman numeral (luminosity class)

starClass.title: Star Class
starClass.description: Star class is a simplified classification of spectral type. Main classes are O, B, A, F, G, K, M from hottest (blue) to coolest (red). Most stars in the galaxy are K or M type red dwarfs. The Sun is a G-type star.
starClass.example: O-type: Hot, bright, short-lived, M-type: Cool, dim, long-lived (most common)
starClass.technicalNote: Derived from spectral type. The letter designation indicates temperature class.

discoveryYear.title: Discovery Year
discoveryYear.description: The year the exoplanet was first confirmed and announced to the scientific community. The first exoplanet was discovered in 1992 orbiting a pulsar, and the first around a Sun-like star in 1995. Discovery dates tell us about the history of exoplanet research.
discoveryYear.example: First exoplanet: 1992, First Sun-like star: 1995, Most recent: 2024
discoveryYear.technicalNote: Year of discovery announcement in the Exoplanet Archive.

discoveryMethod.title: Discovery Method
discoveryMethod.description: The technique used to detect the exoplanet. Transit method (planet blocks starlight) has discovered most exoplanets. Radial Velocity (star wobbles) found the first exoplanet. Direct Imaging (photograph the planet), Microlensing, and Timing Variations are other methods. Each method has strengths and biases.
discoveryMethod.example: Transit: ~70% of exoplanets, Radial Velocity: ~20%, Timing: ~3%, Microlensing: ~3%
discoveryMethod.technicalNote: Different methods detect different types of planets. Transit works best for close-in planets; RV works best for massive planets.
discoveryMethod.funFact: The Kepler mission discovered over 2,600 exoplanets using the transit method!

facility.title: Discovery Facility
facility.description: The observatory, telescope, or mission that made the initial discovery. Famous discoverers include the Kepler Space Telescope, TESS, and ground-based observatories. The facility tells you about the state of technology when the discovery was made.
facility.example: Kepler Space Telescope, TESS, Keck Observatory, VLT (Very Large Telescope), Gaia mission
facility.technicalNote: The observatory or mission listed in the Exoplanet Archive.

semiMajorAxis.title: Semi-Major Axis
semiMajorAxis.description: The semi-major axis is the average distance from a planet to its star. It's measured in astronomical units (AU)‚Äîthe distance from Earth to the Sun. This distance determines how much energy the planet receives and whether it's in the habitable zone.
semiMajorAxis.example: Mercury: 0.39 AU, Earth: 1.0 AU, Mars: 1.52 AU, Jupiter: 5.2 AU
semiMajorAxis.technicalNote: Measured in AU. For circular orbits, it's the orbital radius; for elliptical orbits, it's the average.

orbitalEccentricity.title: Orbital Eccentricity
orbitalEccentricity.description: Eccentricity measures how elongated an orbit is. A value of 0 means a perfect circle, while values close to 1 mean a highly elongated ellipse. High eccentricity can cause extreme temperature swings on a planet as it moves closer and farther from its star.
orbitalEccentricity.example: Earth: 0.017 (nearly circular), Mercury: 0.206 (noticeably elliptical), Some exoplanets: >0.9 (very elongated)
orbitalEccentricity.technicalNote: Dimensionless value between 0 and 1. Measured through orbital variations in radial velocity or transit timing.

transitDepth.title: Transit Depth
transitDepth.description: When a planet passes in front of its star, it blocks a tiny fraction of starlight. This dip in brightness is the transit depth, directly revealing the planet's size relative to its star. Jupiter-sized planets block about 1% of light, while Earth-sized planets block only 0.008%.
transitDepth.example: Jupiter transit: ~1% depth, Earth transit: ~0.008% depth, Hot Jupiter: 1-3%
transitDepth.technicalNote: Measured as percentage or parts-per-million (ppm). Proportional to (R_planet / R_star)¬≤
transitDepth.funFact: The Kepler space telescope could detect brightness changes as small as 0.001%!

transitDuration.title: Transit Duration
transitDuration.description: Transit duration is how long it takes for a planet to completely cross its star's disk. It depends on the planet's orbital velocity and the size of the star. Longer transits occur for planets orbiting slower or around larger stars. This helps confirm detections and measure planet-to-star size ratios.
transitDuration.example: Earth transiting the Sun: ~13 hours, Hot Jupiter: 2-4 hours, Neptune-like: 5-8 hours
transitDuration.technicalNote: Measured in hours. Related to orbital period and semi-major axis.

transitRatio.title: Planet-to-Star Radius Ratio
transitRatio.description: This is the ratio of the planet's radius to the star's radius. It directly affects the transit depth. A planet orbiting a small star can block more light relative to the star's size. This ratio helps characterize the planet and is essential for atmospheric analysis.
transitRatio.technicalNote: Dimensionless ratio. Calculated as R_planet / R_star.

orbitalRatio.title: Orbital Distance-to-Stellar Radius Ratio
orbitalRatio.description: This is the ratio of the semi-major axis to the star's radius. It tells us how close the planet orbits relative to the star's size. Small values mean the planet is very close to its star (close-in planets), while large values mean distant orbits.
orbitalRatio.technicalNote: Dimensionless ratio. Also called 'a/R‚òÖ'. Smaller ratios indicate closer orbits.

impactParameter.title: Impact Parameter
impactParameter.description: The impact parameter describes where the planet's path crosses the star's disk. A value of 0 means the planet passes through the center, while values near 1 mean grazing transits. This determines how much light the planet blocks and helps understand the planetary system's geometry.
impactParameter.example: Central transit: b = 0, Grazing transit: b > 0.9, Missed transit: b > 1
impactParameter.technicalNote: Dimensionless value between 0 and 1. Determined from transit light curves.

rvAmplitude.title: Radial Velocity Amplitude
rvAmplitude.description: Radial velocity (RV) amplitude is the maximum velocity at which a star 'wobbles' due to the gravitational pull of an orbiting planet. Larger amplitude means a more massive planet or shorter orbital period. RV was the first method to discover exoplanets.
rvAmplitude.example: Jupiter's effect on the Sun: 12.5 m/s, Hot Jupiter: 50-500 m/s, Earth's effect on the Sun: 0.09 m/s
rvAmplitude.technicalNote: Measured in meters per second (m/s). Proportional to planet mass and orbital velocity.
rvAmplitude.funFact: To detect Earth's pull on the Sun from afar would require precision beyond current technology!

stellar RV.title: Stellar Radial Velocity
stellar RV.description: This is the star's motion toward or away from Earth due to its orbit around the galaxy and local stellar motions. It's different from the RV caused by planets. Subtracting this 'baseline' RV is necessary to identify planets from RV measurements.
stellar RV.example: Sun: ~7 km/s (toward solar apex), Typical star: -50 to +50 km/s
stellar RV.technicalNote: Measured in km/s. Determined from spectroscopic analysis.

stellar Vsin.title: Stellar Rotation Velocity
stellar Vsin.description: This is the rotation speed of the star at its equator as seen from Earth (it's the sine of the inclination, so we can't see the true speed). Fast-rotating stars make it harder to detect planets via radial velocity because rotation creates noise in the measurements.
stellar Vsin.example: Non-rotating star: < 1 km/s, Sun: 2 km/s, Fast rotator: > 10 km/s
stellar Vsin.technicalNote: Measured in km/s. Determined from spectroscopic line broadening. True velocity is v_rot / sin(i).

habitableZone.title: Habitable Zone
habitableZone.description: The habitable zone (or 'Goldilocks zone') is the region around a star where temperatures allow liquid water to exist on a planet's surface‚Äînot too hot, not too cold. For our Sun, this zone extends from roughly Venus's orbit to Mars's orbit. Being in the habitable zone doesn't guarantee life, but it's a promising sign.
habitableZone.example: Sun's habitable zone: 0.95-1.67 AU, Red dwarf: 0.1-0.3 AU (much closer), Hot star: 2-10 AU (much farther)
habitableZone.technicalNote: Boundaries depend on stellar luminosity and atmospheric models.
habitableZone.funFact: Earth is right in the middle of the Sun's habitable zone, sometimes called the 'perfect distance'!

earthLike.title: Earth-like
earthLike.description: An 'Earth-like' planet is one that shares significant similarities with Earth. This typically means it's a rocky planet in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. However, being Earth-like doesn't mean it's actually habitable‚Äîit just has conditions similar to Earth's.
earthLike.example: Proxima Centauri b is one of the closest potentially Earth-like exoplanets, though it orbits a red dwarf.
earthLike.technicalNote: Definition varies by source. This app uses radius (0.8-1.25 R‚äï), habitable zone location, and rocky composition.
earthLike.funFact: Only a few dozen confirmed exoplanets are considered Earth-like based on current criteria!

topCandidate.title: Top Habitable Candidate
topCandidate.description: A top habitable candidate is a planet that ranks highly in the likelihood of being able to support life. This considers multiple factors including habitable zone location, size, composition, stellar type, and age. These are the planets most worth studying for potential habitability.
topCandidate.technicalNote: Based on habitability scoring algorithms that weight multiple factors.

potentiallyRocky.title: Potentially Rocky
potentiallyRocky.description: A potentially rocky planet is estimated to have a rocky (terrestrial) composition rather than being a gas or ice giant. Rocky planets are more likely to have solid surfaces where life could exist. This classification is based on radius and mass estimates.
potentiallyRocky.example: Small Earth-like planets, Super-Earths, most planets < 2 Earth radii
potentiallyRocky.technicalNote: Classification based on radius and mass. Rocky if R < 1.5 R‚äï typically, or if density suggests rocky composition.

earthLikeInsolation.title: Earth-like Insolation
earthLikeInsolation.description: Earth-like insolation means the planet receives approximately the same amount of stellar energy as Earth does from the Sun. This is a key factor in habitability because it determines surface temperature. Planets with Earth-like insolation are more likely to have liquid water.
earthLikeInsolation.example: Earth: 1.0 S‚äï, Kepler-186f: 0.32 S‚äï (cool but habitable), Hot Jupiters: > 100 S‚äï
earthLikeInsolation.technicalNote: Similar to Earth's insolation (1 S‚äï). Typically defined as 0.25-4 S‚äï.

hotJupiter.title: Hot Jupiter
hotJupiter.description: A hot Jupiter is a gas giant planet orbiting very close to its star‚Äîmuch closer than Mercury orbits the Sun. This was surprising when first discovered because our solar system's gas giants are distant. Hot Jupiters are easy to detect via transit method because they're large and frequently eclipse their stars.
hotJupiter.technicalNote: Typically defined as Jupiter-mass planets with orbital periods < 10 days.

hotNeptune.title: Hot Neptune
hotNeptune.description: A hot Neptune is a Neptune-sized ice giant orbiting close to its star. These planets are thought to be primordial gas giants that migrated inward and lost their outer hydrogen/helium atmospheres due to stellar radiation. They're intermediate between gas giants and rocky planets.
hotNeptune.technicalNote: Typically defined as Neptune-mass planets (4-10 M‚äï) with orbital periods < 10 days.

ultraHot.title: Ultra-Hot Planet
ultraHot.description: An ultra-hot planet is one with an exceptionally high equilibrium temperature, typically > 2,000 K. These planets orbit extremely close to their stars and experience intense radiation. Their atmospheres may be partially stripped away, and they may have molten surfaces.
ultraHot.technicalNote: Typically defined as planets with Teq > 2,000 K or orbital period < 1 day.

frozenWorld.title: Frozen World
frozenWorld.description: A frozen world is a planet with a very low equilibrium temperature, typically < 200 K (-73¬∞C). These planets orbit far from their stars and receive minimal stellar energy. Their surfaces would be covered in ice and frozen gases unless heated by internal processes.
frozenWorld.example: Distant planets around low-luminosity stars, some ice giants
frozenWorld.technicalNote: Typically defined as planets with Teq < 200 K.

ultraDense.title: Ultra-Dense Planet
ultraDense.description: An ultra-dense planet has exceptionally high density, suggesting an iron core or extreme compression. These planets may have experienced core accretion and planetary migration, or lost their atmospheres. Ultra-dense worlds are fundamentally different from anything in our solar system.
ultraDense.technicalNote: Defined by high density relative to size. Typically > 8-10 g/cm¬≥.

puffy.title: Puffy Planet
puffy.description: A puffy planet is surprisingly large for its mass‚Äîit has lower density than expected. These planets may have thick hydrogen/helium atmospheres or be heated so intensely by their stars that their atmospheres puff up. Some are so light they'd float in water!
puffy.technicalNote: Defined by low density relative to size. Density < 0.5 g/cm¬≥ (less dense than water).

superMassive.title: Super-Massive Planet
superMassive.description: A super-massive planet is exceptionally large, typically > 13 Jupiter masses. At this mass, planets approach the deuterium-burning limit and may be considered brown dwarfs. These are the most massive planets known.
superMassive.example: Some massive planets at tens of Jupiter masses
superMassive.technicalNote: Defined as having mass > ~13 M_J, near the hydrogen-burning limit.

lightweight.title: Lightweight Planet
lightweight.description: A lightweight planet has unusually low mass for its size, or small size for its type. These planets are interesting because their low density and/or mass provide clues about formation and atmospheric escape. Some lightweight planets may have lost their atmospheres over time.
lightweight.technicalNote: Defined by mass < 3 M‚äï for Super-Earths, or density lower than expected.

ultraShortPeriod.title: Ultra-Short Period
ultraShortPeriod.description: An ultra-short period planet orbits its star extremely quickly, typically with a period < 1 day. These planets are so close to their stars that they experience intense heat and tidal forces. Some may even be spiraling into their stars.
ultraShortPeriod.technicalNote: Defined as orbital period < 1 day. Some have periods of just a few hours!

longPeriod.title: Long-Period Planet
longPeriod.description: A long-period planet takes more than a year to orbit its star, placing it far from its star. These planets receive little stellar energy and are cold. Long-period planets are often harder to detect because we need years of observations to confirm the orbit.
longPeriod.example: Planets with periods > 1 year or > 365 days
longPeriod.technicalNote: Defined as orbital period > 365 days (Earth years).

eccentricOrbit.title: Eccentric Orbit
eccentricOrbit.description: An eccentric orbit is elongated rather than circular. Planets with eccentric orbits experience extreme temperature variations as they move closer and farther from their star. This is unusual because orbital interactions tend to circularize orbits over time.
eccentricOrbit.example: Some exoplanets with e > 0.2 or higher

circularOrbit.title: Circular Orbit
circularOrbit.description: A circular orbit is nearly perfectly round, providing stable, consistent conditions for planets. Our Earth has one of the most circular orbits (e = 0.017). Circular orbits suggest the system is old and stable.
circularOrbit.example: Earth: e = 0.017, Venus: e = 0.007 (nearly perfect circles)

tidallyLocked.title: Likely Tidally Locked
tidallyLocked.description: A tidally locked planet always shows the same face to its star‚Äîone side perpetually faces the star while the other faces away. This happens for planets very close to their stars. The day side is extremely hot while the night side is freezing cold.
tidallyLocked.example: Most hot Jupiters, many ultra-hot planets, Mercury-like close-in planets
tidallyLocked.technicalNote: Likely if orbital period and semi-major axis suggest tidal locking is complete.

circumbinary.title: Circumbinary
circumbinary.description: A circumbinary planet orbits two stars instead of one. These are rare and fascinating‚Äîplanets must orbit far enough out to avoid destabilizing interactions with the binary pair. They have more complex dynamics but could potentially have two suns in their sky.
circumbinary.technicalNote: Binary stars with planets orbiting both. Requires careful orbital calculations.

multiPlanet.title: Multi-Planet System
multiPlanet.description: A multi-planet system has more than one confirmed exoplanet orbiting the same star. These systems are valuable because we can study planet interactions and formation. Most known exoplanets are in systems with multiple planets.
multiPlanet.example: TRAPPIST-1 (7 planets), Kepler-90 (8 planets), Our solar system (8 planets)
multiPlanet.technicalNote: Simply means sy_pnum > 1 in the data.

richSystem.title: Rich System
richSystem.description: A rich system has many planets orbiting the same star, typically 5 or more. These systems are treasure troves for understanding planetary formation. Compact systems with many planets packed close together are especially interesting.
richSystem.example: TRAPPIST-1 (7), Kepler-90 (8), Gliese 667 (at least 5 visible planets)

multiStar.title: Multi-Star System
multiStar.description: A multi-star system has planets orbiting around multiple stars rather than just one. This includes both circumbinary planets and planets in wide binary systems. Planets in these systems experience more complex gravitational dynamics.
multiStar.example: Alpha Centauri, Sirius system, many multiple star systems
multiStar.technicalNote: Indicated by sy_snum > 1 (more than one stellar component).

veryNearby.title: Very Nearby
veryNearby.description: A very nearby planet orbits a star within 10 light-years of Earth. These are the closest exoplanets and are prime targets for future observation and potential interstellar missions. Proxima Centauri b is our nearest exoplanet neighbor.
veryNearby.example: Proxima Centauri b (4.2 ly), TRAPPIST-1e (12 ly)

nearby.title: Nearby
nearby.description: A nearby planet orbits a star between 10 and 50 light-years away. These planets are close enough for detailed study with current and near-future telescopes. Many important exoplanet discoveries are in nearby systems.
nearby.example: Epsilon Eridani (10.5 ly), Tau Ceti (12 ly), Vega (25 ly)

solarAnalog.title: Solar Analog
solarAnalog.description: A solar analog is a star very similar to our Sun‚Äîsame temperature, size, mass, and age. Planets orbiting solar analogs are especially interesting because we can compare their systems to our own. Finding Earth analogs around solar analogs is a major goal.
solarAnalog.example: Sun-like stars with similar T_eff, radius, and age as our 4.6 billion-year-old Sun
solarAnalog.technicalNote: Defined by similar stellar parameters to the Sun.

redDwarfHost.title: Red Dwarf Host
redDwarfHost.description: A red dwarf host is a small, cool M-type star hosting exoplanet(s). Red dwarfs are the most common stars and live for trillions of years. Their habitable zones are much closer than for Sun-like stars, making their planets easier to detect.

youngSystem.title: Young System
youngSystem.description: A young system has an age < 500 million years or so. Young planetary systems are still forming and evolving‚Äîplanets may be migrating, and residual dust and debris are common. These systems help us understand planetary formation.
youngSystem.example: Systems around young stars in star-forming regions

ancientSystem.title: Ancient System
ancientSystem.description: An ancient system has an age > 10 billion years‚Äîit's older than our solar system. Ancient systems are stable and settled. Finding planets around ancient stars tells us about long-term system stability.
ancientSystem.example: Some systems with M-type stars or in globular clusters

metalRich.title: Metal-Rich Star
metalRich.description: A metal-rich star has higher abundance of elements heavier than helium than our Sun does. Metal-rich stars are more likely to host planets, especially gas giants. This suggests that metallicity correlates with planet formation efficiency.
metalRich.funFact: Exoplanet host stars are statistically more metal-rich than average stars!

metalPoor.title: Metal-Poor Star
metalPoor.description: A metal-poor star has lower abundance of heavy elements than our Sun. Metal-poor stars are less likely to host planets. These ancient stars are often found in globular clusters and tell us about the early universe.

transiting.title: Transiting
transiting.description: A transiting planet passes in front of its star from our perspective, causing a measurable dip in starlight. These planets are ideal for study because we can observe their transits repeatedly and measure their size, composition, and atmospheric properties.
transiting.technicalNote: Directly observed to transit based on light curve data.

hasRvData.title: Has Radial Velocity Data
hasRvData.description: This planet has radial velocity measurements showing the star's wobble caused by the planet's gravity. RV data allows us to measure the planet's minimum mass. Combined with transit data, RV gives us the true mass.
hasRvData.example: Planets discovered via or confirmed by RV method
hasRvData.technicalNote: RV amplitude (pl_rvamp) is measured and available.

hasTtv.title: Has Transit Timing Variations
hasTtv.description: Transit timing variations (TTVs) occur when planets gravitationally interact with each other, causing slight variations in transit times. TTV can reveal the masses of planets and detect non-transiting planets in multi-planet systems.
hasTtv.example: Planets in Kepler multi-planet systems showing TTV signals

controversial.title: Controversial
controversial.description: A controversial planet's existence is debated or not fully confirmed. This might be due to weak signals, conflicting data, or alternative explanations for observations. These planets require additional follow-up observations.
controversial.example: Some marginal detections or claims requiring confirmation
controversial.technicalNote: Marked in the Exoplanet Archive as controversial or unconfirmed.
